q3.value: Research has demonstrated that pleasant touch modulates the communication of affect and social decision making. However, it is not known if this effect extends to how we perceive and share the affective states of others - i.e. our empathy. Moreover, previous research has relied upon experimental paradigms that lack ecological validity. Addressing these shortcomings, the present research aims to test the extent to which empathic responding is modulated by affective touch, using paradigms that vary in their ecological validity.

q4.value:
H1 Participants' empathic response to emotionally evocative stimuli will increase after receiving affective touch administered using a forearm stoking paradigm

H2 Participants' empathic response to emotionally evocative stimuli will increase after receiving affective touch administered as an embrace

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: We will conduct two experiments. The first will involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. The second experiment also uses human subjects and no blinding is involved.

question.value:
Experiment 1:

Participants (n=40, 100% female) will begin the experiment by watching a series of 32 video clips (approximately 30 seconds each), split into 2 blocks. In block 1 participants will be asked to continuously rate how upset they feel as they watch the clips (using a dimensional rating tool anchored with the labels ‘not upset at all’ to ‘very upset’), in block 2 they will be asked to continuously rate how upset they perceive the individual portrayed in the clip to be. Half of the clips will portray individuals describing emotionally evocative events they have previously experienced (i.e. ‘emotional videos’), the other half will portray individuals describing events that they do not consider emotionally evocative (i.e. ‘neutral videos’; e.g. daily routines). After watching each video clip, participants will then provide a summative rating of either the emotion they experienced or perceived (countering the instruction of the continuous ratings). Video clips will be presented in a randomised order (within blocks), block order will be counterbalanced across participants.

After the two blocks of clips, participants will receive 10 seconds of stroking on their left ventral forearm using a soft make-up brush. Half of the participants will receive affective touch, operationalised as slow (5 cm/s) stroking, the other half will receive affectively neutral, fast (20 cm/s) stroking. Between-subjects stroking conditions will be counterbalanced. Post-touch intervention, participants will watch and rate another set of video clips (portraying different individuals) in a procedure identical to the pre-touch set.

Experiment 2:

Following a procedure similar to that of Experiment 1, participants (n=40, 100% female) will begin the experiment by watching a series of 32 video clips, split into 2 blocks. Participants will then share 10 seconds of a criss-cross embrace with the experimenter or stand up for 10s. This between-subject condition will be counterbalanced again. Post-embrace procedure will be the same as in experiment 1. 

The design of both experiments is mixed: there will be an experimental group that experiences an affective touch intervention and a control group that does not; with both groups having their empathy measured pre- and post-intervention. In both experiments the independent variable is the experience of affective touch, the dependent variables are participants’ overall empathy ratings.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: 18-65 years old, female only. Participants will be recruited using convenience sampling from a university campus in London (UK). Sample will be restricted to females to avoid touch-induced gender effects. 

Exclusion criteria: current diagnosis of severe mental health issues, neurological disorder, skin disease, or Autism Spectrum Disorder.

Payment: course credit (for undergraduate students) or financial compensation (no more than £10)

Timeline: Data collection will begin February 2020, with a projected completion date of December 2020. Analysis to begin as soon as data collection is complete.

q13.value:
Experiment 1 and 2:
40 participants in total
	20 for each touch condition (affective touch vs. control)

q14.value: In order to detect a medium effect size (f = .25) with α = .05 and β = .80 in a 2x2 repeated measures/mixed design a total of 98 participants is required for the between factors effects, and 34 for the within factors effects. Due to resource and time constraints it is not possible to reach the required n of 98 for detection of the between factors effects (an n of 80 being the closest possible). Power calculations performed using G*Power software.

question.value:
Experiment 1:
Independent variable: type of stroking, 2 levels. 
	Affective touch: Slow, 5 cm/s stroking 
	Non-affective touch (control): Fast, 20 cm/s stroking

Experiment 2:
Independent variable: touch, 2 levels
	Affective touch: 10 second criss-cross embrace 
	Non-touch (control): 10 seconds standing up

Experiments 1 and 2:
Dependent variables (A): empathy ratings, 4 fully factorial ratings
	Mean of continuous ratings for self
	Mean of continuous ratings for other
	Summary/overall ratings for self
	Summary/overall ratings for other
Dependent variable (B):
        Pleasure ratings of touch/break
N/A

For experiments 1 and 2 the analysis strategy will be similar, for each empathy measure we will conduct a 2-way mixed ANOVA. The within-subjects factor will be the empathy measure at pre-intervention and post-intervention, and the between-subjects factor will be touch intervention type (affective touch vs control). We are not interested in interaction effects. If significant main effects of intervention-type on empathy ratings are found, we will use post-hoc pairwise comparisons (t-tests) to investigate the direction of the effect. As a manipulation check, we will use an independent samples t-test in each experiment to check whether the affective touch intervention was more pleasant than the control intervention. The corresponding non-parametric tests will be used in the case of non-normally distributed data.

q21.value:
We will evaluate the results of the ANOVAs by focusing on effect size (partial eta squared) and statistical significance levels (α = .05).

For pairwise comparisons (t-tests) we will calculate and evaluate effect size (Cohen's d) and statistical significance values (α = .05).

attributes.title: Milestones in the transition from non-oral feeding to oral feeding in preterm infants: a scoping review.
attributes.description:
The crucial aim of scoping review is the identification of the steps that the premature infants experience during the development of swallowing skills, going from non-oral feeding until reaching full oral feeding. 

The project has a general and broad purpose because of the area chosen. It is well recognized that premature infants could have difficulties initiating oral feeding. However, the weight of this challenge, as well as the steps that the premature babies pass by, going through nonoral feeding or disorganized feeding to complete oral feeding, are not fully understood.
 
For the reasons above mentioned, the following research question was identified: 
How does the literature describe the developmental trajectory of feeding, eating, drinking, and swallowing skills for preterm infants who show signs of an abnormal swallow, as they progress from non-oral feeding to oral feeding?

Accordingly, the first project aim summarized how the different types of research in the literature describe the swallowing development in premature babies. This objective focused on the procedure that clinicians utilized in their recommendation of feeding difficulties. In addition, attention was given to the outcome measures as well as the description used to define the swallowing function. 

The subsequent aim was the identification of the main steps which the premature population follow from the non-oral feeding until they complete oral feeding. Accordingly, the expectation was to define a clearer image of all the milestones that the premature population could pass through during the swallowing maturation. 

In conclusion, the expectation is to describe the swallowing development phases of the studied population. By examining the pathway that premature infants go over the first period of life, the chance of a positive impact on clinicians' awareness of it is auspicial. Likewise, a deeper understanding of procedures and practice for the description steps could serve at the clinicians as a practice guide for assessment and intervention readiness.

attributes.title: Social support and reduced pain experience: The role of mental representation of social support

q1.value: Social support and reduced pain experience: The role of mental representation of social support

q3.value:
Past research has shown that that the mere presence of another supportive individual (vs. being alone) reduced pain ratings in a cold pressor task (Brown et al., 2003; but see McClelland & McCubbin, 2008) and reduced pain ratings among fibromyalgia patients following stimulation to a painful body site (Montoya, Larbig, Braun, Preissl, & Birbaumer, 2004). Our goal is to expand this findings, and test wheather the mental representation of important other can produce the same effects of the physical presence of an important other. 
Based on evidence showing that the mental representations of important others can produce effects similar to those created by the actual presence of these individuals (Fitzsimons & Bargh, 2003; Mikulincer & Shaver, 2001), we support the idea that the mere representation of an important other could procude the same pain-attenuating effects of social support observed in previous research.

q4.value:
If our raltionat id true, the physical presence and the mental representation of a partner (vs. control condition) should decrease participants’ reported levels of pain experience. No difference between the condition of physical presence and mental representation of a partner is expected (Hypothesis 1).

Hypothesis 2: No difference of reported levels of pain should be observed .

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three experimental conditions (physical social support vs menatal representation of social support vs control gorup) with a random draw. Participants assigned to the physical social support codntion will be asked to come at the laboratory with their partner. Participants assigned to the mental representation social support codntion will be asked to come at the laboratory with a photograhp of their partner.
After arriving at the laboratory, participants will be set in the laboratory and wait until the experimenter is ready. In the physical support condition, the supporting partner will be given instruction about their role in the experiment, which was to take the hand of their partner in silence, while we have the hand in the cold water. 
Participants in the mental representation support condition will be asked to take out their photo and wait until the experimenter is ready. Participants in the control condition will wait without any instruction. 

Whant the experimenter is ready, participants will be administated a coul pressure task. 
Following the procedure of Brown, Sheffield, Leary, & Robinson (2003), participants will be asked to place their nondominant hand into the water maintained at 1 to 2°C. Participants will be  instructed to refrain from moving their hand while it will be immersed and to keep their hand in the water until the sensations is too uncomfortable, and for a maximum of 3 minutes. They will be asked to rate how much pain they experience every 20 seconds while their hand is immersed by pointing to a number on a 7-point scale, where 1 (none) and 7 (extreme). 
After which, participants will be tanked and debriefed.

The Study is a 3 between subject experimental design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited in public spaces (e.g., cafés, street, etc). Only couples will be approached, and will be invited to take part in the experiment. The participation is volontary, and no reward is planned. 
The study will take place in the experimenter’s university laboratory, and all data will be collected by the same female experimenter. In order to activate social support, participants will be asked to hold the hand of their partner while doing the experience (physical presence condition) or viewing the photograph of their partner (mental representation condition). Thus, only participants that are in a relationship will be recruited.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 132 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 200, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: Based on pas research examining the relation between social support and pain experience (Brown et al., 2003), we run a power analysis with G*Power. The analysis was run for an One-way, fixed effects, omnibus model. The effect size f was calculated based on the partial n2 of the interaction between condition and time point, reported in Brown et al. (2003). Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a small effect size of .07 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: Experimenter will recruit subjects in streets, cafés, ect. We will have 2 month to recruit 200 subjects. If after 2 month we will be below 200 participants, the experimenter will recrute for a supplementary month.

question.value: We manipulated the social support. The three levels of this categorical variable are: mental representation of partner vs physical presence of partner vs control condition.

The single outcome variable will be Self-reported pain experience. This variable will be measured 9 times during the cold pressure task (each 20 seconds) for a maximum of 3 minutes. Scale range from 1 (none) and 7 (extreme).
We will take the mean for each condition of the self-reported pain experience.
We will compare the mean reported pain across the two experimental and control conditions using a one-way ANOVA and Tukey post hoc comparison tests.

q22.value: Participants that do not stand the 3 minutes with the hand in the cold water will be excluded from analysis.

attributes.title: Generating the face of a character

q1.value: Generating the face of a character without frowned eyebrows using FaceGen

q2.value: Sabine Windmann, Lisa Steinbrück, Patrick Stier

q3.value: The study is part of a series of studies in which observer biases in the association of fWHR of males with aggressive-dominant and power-seeking behavioral traits are assessed through a photo-editing task using the program FaceGen. Previous studies from our lab found the relationship to be mediated by state-emotionality, especially anger. In this study, we will eliminate the FaceGen sliders by which frowned eyebrows can be modelled. We ask whether fWHR will still be larger for powerful male characters compared to powerless. This is the primary research question of the study. In addition, we will compare aggressive-dominant versus peaceloving-submissive character conditions between subjects to determine the size of the effect.

q4.value:
If an observer bias exists above and beyond what independent raters consider to reflect state-emotionality, fWHR will be larger in the powerful condition compared to powerless (and, likewise, in the aggressive-dominant condition compared to peaceloving-submissive). 

The fact is, we do not expect any observer bias outside of state emotionality; we really expect a null effect. If any effect emerges despite our changes made to FaceGen, it will vanish when state-emotionality is used as a covariate in the analysis.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
Regarding powerful/powerless: within subject's design with 1 factor and 2 levels. 
Regarding aggressive-dominant/peaceloving-submissive: between subject's design with 1 factor and 2 levels.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited on campus via flyer and social media. They will be given either 60 minutes course credit, or 5 Euro for participation and a little gift worth less than Euro 2.
Excluded are only those participants who have participated in a previous study in this series of studies using FaceGen. 
After data collection, we ask whether they knew of the research question, and whether they had modelled a real person (as opposed to a fictional character). Both will lead to exclusion of their data.

q13.value: We will collect data from N=110 individuals. This includes an anticipated number of 4 individuals that may have to be excluded.

q14.value:
For the within-subjects comparison (powerful vs powerless), according to the program G*Power, N=106 is needed to detect a medium-sized effect of f=.25 at an error probability alpha of p=.05. The power for this analysis is .95, meaning that if no significant difference is found, the null hypothesis can be maintained at a beta error probability of p=.05. 

For the between-subjects comparison (aggressive-dominant vs. peaceloving-submissive), stronger effects are expected based on our prior study (1a), where eta square was .31 (f=.65). According to G*Power, a univariate ANOVA requires only N=34 to detect effects of this size. With the collection of N=110, we will be able to detect medium to strong effects sized f=.30 at both alpha=.05 and beta=.05.

question.value:
We will manipulate by instruction the character that participants are asked to model. 
Participants begin with the two conditions powerful and powerless (with order of conditions counterbalanced between participants). 
The third condition is always either aggressive-dominant or peaceloving-submissive (quasi-random assignment); these two conditions will be compared between participants.

fWHR will be measured as distance between outer edge of cheekbones divided by the distance from upper edge of upper lips to lower edge of eyebrows. This is the main dependent measure.  State emotionality will be rated on a scale fom 0 to 6. This is the covariate. Type of basic emotion will be coded for exploratory analyses. 

One alternative measure of height will be taken, namely the distance from upper lip to nasion. If any effects of state emotionality are found in the main analysis, then the ANOVA will be repeated with fWHR computed with this measure of height.

We will use ANOVA with repeated measures for the comparison of powerful vs. powerless and univariate ANOVA for the comparison of aggressive-dominant vs. peaceloving-submissive. In both analyses, if there is an effect of condition, we will use state-emotionality as rated by two blind reviewers as covariate.

q21.value: We will use two-tailed tests as customarily done.

q22.value:
see above. Participants will be excluded if they either state that they know of the research question (specifically, facial width is associated with behavioral traits), or if they state that they have modeled a real person (as opposed to a fictitious character). 
Pictures are also excluded if raters state that they do not display human faces (i.e., monsters, freaks).

q25.value:
The primary comparison is powerful vs. powerless, and is therefore performed at p=.05. 
The comparison between subjects (aggressive-dominant versus peaceloving-submissive) is only an addendum to estimate the size of this effect.

registration_responses.q1: Generating the face of a character without frowned eyebrows using FaceGen
registration_responses.q2: Sabine Windmann, Lisa Steinbrück, Patrick Stier
registration_responses.q3: The study is part of a series of studies in which observer biases in the association of fWHR of males with aggressive-dominant and power-seeking behavioral traits are assessed through a photo-editing task using the program FaceGen. Previous studies from our lab found the relationship to be mediated by state-emotionality, especially anger. In this study, we will eliminate the FaceGen sliders by which frowned eyebrows can be modelled. We ask whether fWHR will still be larger for powerful male characters compared to powerless. This is the primary research question of the study. In addition, we will compare aggressive-dominant versus peaceloving-submissive character conditions between subjects to determine the size of the effect.
registration_responses.q4:
If an observer bias exists above and beyond what independent raters consider to reflect state-emotionality, fWHR will be larger in the powerful condition compared to powerless (and, likewise, in the aggressive-dominant condition compared to peaceloving-submissive). 

The fact is, we do not expect any observer bias outside of state emotionality; we really expect a null effect. If any effect emerges despite our changes made to FaceGen, it will vanish when state-emotionality is used as a covariate in the analysis.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will collect data from N=110 individuals. This includes an anticipated number of 4 individuals that may have to be excluded.
registration_responses.q14:
For the within-subjects comparison (powerful vs powerless), according to the program G*Power, N=106 is needed to detect a medium-sized effect of f=.25 at an error probability alpha of p=.05. The power for this analysis is .95, meaning that if no significant difference is found, the null hypothesis can be maintained at a beta error probability of p=.05. 

For the between-subjects comparison (aggressive-dominant vs. peaceloving-submissive), stronger effects are expected based on our prior study (1a), where eta square was .31 (f=.65). According to G*Power, a univariate ANOVA requires only N=34 to detect effects of this size. With the collection of N=110, we will be able to detect medium to strong effects sized f=.30 at both alpha=.05 and beta=.05.
registration_responses.q21: We will use two-tailed tests as customarily done.
registration_responses.q22:
see above. Participants will be excluded if they either state that they know of the research question (specifically, facial width is associated with behavioral traits), or if they state that they have modeled a real person (as opposed to a fictitious character). 
Pictures are also excluded if raters state that they do not display human faces (i.e., monsters, freaks).
registration_responses.q25:
The primary comparison is powerful vs. powerless, and is therefore performed at p=.05. 
The comparison between subjects (aggressive-dominant versus peaceloving-submissive) is only an addendum to estimate the size of this effect.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Regarding powerful/powerless: within subject's design with 1 factor and 2 levels. 
Regarding aggressive-dominant/peaceloving-submissive: between subject's design with 1 factor and 2 levels.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited on campus via flyer and social media. They will be given either 60 minutes course credit, or 5 Euro for participation and a little gift worth less than Euro 2.
Excluded are only those participants who have participated in a previous study in this series of studies using FaceGen. 
After data collection, we ask whether they knew of the research question, and whether they had modelled a real person (as opposed to a fictional character). Both will lead to exclusion of their data.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We will manipulate by instruction the character that participants are asked to model. 
Participants begin with the two conditions powerful and powerless (with order of conditions counterbalanced between participants). 
The third condition is always either aggressive-dominant or peaceloving-submissive (quasi-random assignment); these two conditions will be compared between participants.
registration_responses.q17.question:
fWHR will be measured as distance between outer edge of cheekbones divided by the distance from upper edge of upper lips to lower edge of eyebrows. This is the main dependent measure.  State emotionality will be rated on a scale fom 0 to 6. This is the covariate. Type of basic emotion will be coded for exploratory analyses. 

One alternative measure of height will be taken, namely the distance from upper lip to nasion. If any effects of state emotionality are found in the main analysis, then the ANOVA will be repeated with fWHR computed with this measure of height.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use ANOVA with repeated measures for the comparison of powerful vs. powerless and univariate ANOVA for the comparison of aggressive-dominant vs. peaceloving-submissive. In both analyses, if there is an effect of condition, we will use state-emotionality as rated by two blind reviewers as covariate.

attributes.title: Review of school psychology articles: A snapshot of school psychology research in the last three years
attributes.description:
The purpose of this research is to better understand the types and focus of research published during the past five years. Bliss et al. (2005) found that, despite the applied focus of school psychology, very few experimental studies were conducted in generalist school psychology journals. Additionally, Bliss and colleagues found that few published papers in their five year window had female scientists as first-authors. This study replicates Bliss et al (2005), reviews the past 5 years (2015-2019) to detect recent trends, and extends past research by investigating whether school psychological research has adopted open science practices. We adopt strategies developed by Price et al (2011). This project is largely descriptive/exploratory.

The project is a collaboration project across two labs.

q1.value: Review of school psychology articles: A snapshot of school psychology research in the last five years

q3.value:
The purpose of this research is to better understand the types and focus of research published during the past five years. Bliss et al. (2005) found that, despite the applied focus of school psychology, very few experimental studies were conducted in generalist school psychology journals. Additionally, Bliss and colleagues found that few published papers in their five year window had female scientists as first-authors. This study replicates Bliss et al (2005), reviews the past 5 years (2015-2019) to detect recent trends, and extends past research by investigating whether school psychological research has adopted open science practices. We adopt strategies developed by Price et al (2011). This project is largely descriptive/exploratory.

Research Questions:

1) What type of papers are being published in school psychology (e.g., experimental, correlational, reviews) over the past five years?
2) Given Bliss et al (2005) called for an increase in experimental research, has experimental research increased since the 2000-2005 estimates?
3) Are women publishing more first-author manuscripts now compared to 2000-2005?
4) Are studies using open science practices (e.g., preregistration, open data, open code)? 
5) Are researchers publishing replication studies?

q4.value:
1) If it is true that experimental research in the literature has increased since Bliss et al. (2005), we anticipate seeing a percentage increase in experimental studies compared to Bliss et al.. 

2) We anticipate the percentage of correlational studies will be higher than the percentage of experimental studies over the last three years.

3) We anticipate the percentage of narrative/professional articles will be higher than the percentage of experimental studies over the last three years.

4) Without clear data, we suspect a difference between the number of first-author publications by gender. 

5) We anticipate that few researchers are using open science practices in school psychology. Individually, we will assess whether a meaningful percentage (5%) of papers for each (1) open code, (2) open data, and (3) presence of preregistration. We anticipate that fewer than 2% of empirical articles (e.g., correlational or experimental) will have preregistration.

6) We anticipate that fewer than 5 replication studies per journal will be identified over the past 5 years.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The research team will review the past 5 years of articles published in active generalist school psychology journals. That list includes (a) Journal of School Psychology, (b) Psychology in the Schools, (c) School Psychology International, (d) School Psychology Review, (e) Trainers Forum, (f) Canadian Journal of School Psychology, (g) School Psychology (Quarterly), (h) Journal of Applied School Psychology, (i) Contemporary School Psychology,and the (j) International Journal of School & Educational Psychology. See the attached coding document with details.

Journals will be assigned to a single student prior to double coding. The student will create an excel sheet that includes citation and a complete indicator. This will help students to track which articles have and have not been reviewed. It will also facilitate random assignment of articles per journal for double coding. 

Coding will be completed via Qualtrics form (see attached) following the variables & codebook document, which includes search instructions (see attached). The Qualtrics form is built to route coders to appropriate questions given their previous responses in an effort to minimize error and reduce review time.

Coding Reliability

Initially, research assistants will be trained to code articles based on the variable codebook. The video training will walk research assistants through the concepts, definitions, and terms. It will discuss the procedures for locating and recording study details. Additionally, it will walk research assistants through the coding of two articles with a PI. Next, research assistants will  individually code 8 preselected articles and will be required to have reliability of .9 prior to proceeding with coding for the study. Re-training will be completed with research assistants who had agreement lower than .9. 

After the completion of each individual journal, double coding will occur. If the agreement between coders is below .8, retraining will occur and the journal will be recoded. At the end of the study. 20% of articles will be double-coded to ensure reliable coding (80%). 20% should provide a reasonable sample of articles and permit an accurate estimate of reliability; if the reliability estimate is .85 or below, a more comprehensive double coding process will be used.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Hulac et al (2018) provided a synopsis of publication trends, but did so using citation metrics rather than articles. This will be the first exploration of open science practices. Price et al. (2011) used Bliss et al's approach, but assessed those articles that are cited the most in school psychology and described trends among "citation classics." To the best of our knowledge, the data we are seeking to analyze has never been collected.

question.value:
The research team will review the past 5 (2015-2019) years of articles published in active generalist school psychology journals. That list includes (a) Journal of School Psychology, (b) Psychology in the Schools, (c) School Psychology International, (d) School Psychology Review, (e) Trainers Forum, (f) Canadian Journal of School Psychology, (g) School Psychology (Quarterly), (h) Journal of Applied School Psychology, (i) Contemporary School Psychology, (j) International Journal of School & Educational Psychology. All published manuscripts will be reviewed. Adequate reliability (90%) for each coder will be established at the beginning of the study through double-coding with a PI. Retraining in the coding system will occur if the assistant drops below 90%. 

Journals will be assigned to a single student prior to double coding. The student will use an excel sheet that includes citation and a complete indicator. This will help students to track which articles have and have not been reviewed. It will also facilitate random assignment of articles per journal for double coding. 

Coding will be completed via Qualtrics form (see attached) following the variables & codebook document, which includes search instructions (see attached). The Qualtrics form is built to route coders to appropriate questions given their previous responses in an effort to minimize error.

Coding Reliability

Initially, research assistants will be trained to code articles based on the variable codebook. The video training will walk research assistants through the concepts, definitions, and terms. It will discuss the procedures for locating and recording codes. Additionally, it will walk research assistants through the coding of two articles with a PI. Next, research assistants will code 8 preselected articles on their own and will be required to have reliability of .9 prior to proceeding with coding for the study. Re-training will be completed with research assistants who had agreement lower than .9. 

After the completion of each individual journal, double coding will occur. If the agreement between coders is below .8, retraining will occur and the journal will be recoded. At the end of the study. 20% of articles will be double-coded to ensure reliable coding (80%). 20% should provide a reasonable sample of articles and permit an accurate estimate of reliability; if the reliability estimate is .85 or below, a more comprehensive double coding process will be used.

q13.value: Each article will serve as an individual unit, nested within a journal. Without having collected data at this time, we estimate that approximately 392 articles are published in these core journal each year. This should lead to a sample size of 1,960 across five years. Per journal, the number of articles published varies substantially (from 20 to 100 per year).

q14.value: Given that we are able to sample the universe of manuscripts within the journals we are interested in, we have not conducted an a priori power analysis. Once we have a better estimate of our sample size (units per journal), we may conduct a sensitivity analysis to determine the smallest effect size difference we could reasonably detect. This may be useful should we find no difference between previous and current estimates.

q15.value: We will not use a stopping rule.

question.value: N/A -- non experimental study.
See coding form.
None.

We will complete a "N-1" Chi-Square proportion test as recommended by Campbell (2007) and Richardson (2011) with confidence intervals (Altman et al., 2000). The following proportions (and 95% CI) will be tested.

1) Obtained percentage of experimental studies (x) v. the obtained percentage of experimental studies in Bliss et al. (2008), which was 8% (n = 929). (Are we publishing more experimental studies now versus 2005?).

2) Obtained percentage of experimental studies (x) v. the obtained percentage of correlational studies (y). (Are we publishing more experimental studies or correlational studies in the last 3 years?)

3) Obtained percentage of experimental studies (x) v. the obtained percentage of professional or narrative papers (z). (Are we publishing more experimental studies or narrative/professional papers in the last 3 years?)

4) The percentage of articles in the last three year first-authored by women (w%) and by men (m%) will be different. (We suspect a difference between the number of first-author publications by gender).

5) The percentage of articles in the last three years that include Open Code (oc%) will be compared to a "trivial" percentage of papers (2%). (Are school psychology researchers sharing the code used in their analyses?)

6) The percentage of articles in the last three years that include Open Data (od%) will be compared to a "trivial" percentage of papers (2%). (Are school psychology researchers sharing the data used in their analyses?)

7) The percentage of articles in the last three years that preregistered (pre%) will be compared to a "trivial" percentage of papers (2%). (Are school psychology researchers preregistering their studies?)

q21.value: As the first three analyses, 1, 2, and 3, all focus on comparisons of the number of experimental studies against other categories, there is clear theoretical overlap (Lakens et al., 2018). To account for this, Bonferroni family-wise alpha correction will be used. This results in a per-test alpha of .0169. Similarly, analyses 4, 5, and 6 share a confound (i.e., the three practices described are components of open science practices). and so the per-test alpha of .0169 will be used there as well. There is no overlap between these two sets of analyses (the first focusing on comparisons against the number of experimental studies and the second focusing on open science practices) with one another or analysis four, which focuses on authorship by gender. Family-wise alpha need not be corrected for all analyses, only those with theoretical overlap (see Lakens, 2016; Lakens et al., 2018). The chi-square test is essentially always a one-sided, goodness-of-fit est. Hypothesis/analysis specific criteria are specified in Statistical Models.

q23.value: If an article has been coded and has missing/incomplete data that is expected to be present (e.g., sample size when an empirical paper), then an author will return to the source document to attempt to correct this error.

q24.value: Within categories, we are also interested in the topics of the papers (e.g., social/emotional, academic), participant type, and so forth. We will calculate descriptive data grouped by type of paper. At this time, no other exploratory analyses are planned.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Peer Support Specialists and the Rural Opioids Epidemic: a Pilot Intervention

sample.value: All 177 participants in the OREGON-HOPE cohort will be included in this analysis. All cohort members were invited to utilize peer support services.

analyses.value: Prior to analyses, participant characteristics will be described for the overall sample using univariate statistics (e.g. means, percentages). We will conduct two logistic regression analyses corresponding to each dependent variable. Predictors to test in each model include participant demographic characteristics, variables related to healthcare and SUD treatment access, incarceration, drug and alcohol use, overdose history, previous engagement in SUD treatment, substance use-related stigma, and HCV infection. Variables will be entered into models individually, and all showing significant association with the outcome at p < .1 will be included in a multivariable model. Variables of a priori importance based on prior literature (e.g. gender and methamphetamine use) may be retained in the model regardless of statistical significance in bivariate analysis. We will report bivariate and multivariable results for each model. Models will be fit using generalized estimating equations (GEE) to account for clustering of individuals within RDS chains (clustering is defined at the seed level) with covariance structures chosen to best fit the data. RDS weights will not be included in the analyses as simulations have noted substantial bias and highly inflated type-I error rates in weighted regression models (https://doi.org/10.1186/s12874-019-0842-5). As sensitivity analyses, we may also consider other methods of variable selection to identify predictors of engagement, e.g. LASSO regression or random forest analysis.

outliers.value: We will not exclude "outliers", but clinically impossible observations may be discarded. However, a review of the descriptive statistics for predictors of interest does not reveal any observations that are likely to be excluded.

dependent.value:
There are two key dependent variables corresponding to the two aims.

1: Acceptance of any peer support services, including counseling, housing assistance, transportation, legal issues, and others.
2: Acceptance of peer referral for SUD treatment, including residential and outpatient treatment as well as medications to treat substance use disorders.

Peer support specialists affiliated with participating community health organizations enter data on service utilization into participant medical records. These data are then abstracted into the study database for analyses.

conditions.value: This is an exploratory analysis of factors associated with utilization of peer support services and does not test the effect of a particular condition or exposure

hypothesis.value:
The goal of the current study is to test the development, feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary impact of a rural peer support specialist outreach intervention for engaging people with opioid use disorder and other substance use disorders (SUDs) in treatment. We aim to answer two questions:

1) What factors are associated with engagement in the peer support services intervention? 
2) What factors are associated with acceptance of peer referral for SUD treatment?

We also describe development of the rural peer intervention.

1: Acceptance of any peer support services, including counseling, housing assistance, transportation, legal issues, and others.
2: Acceptance of peer referral for SUD treatment, including residential and outpatient treatment as well as medications to treat substance use disorders.

Peer support specialists affiliated with participating community health organizations enter data on service utilization into participant medical records. These data are then abstracted into the study database for analyses.
registration_responses.conditions: This is an exploratory analysis of factors associated with utilization of peer support services and does not test the effect of a particular condition or exposure
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The goal of the current study is to test the development, feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary impact of a rural peer support specialist outreach intervention for engaging people with opioid use disorder and other substance use disorders (SUDs) in treatment. We aim to answer two questions:

1) What factors are associated with engagement in the peer support services intervention? 
2) What factors are associated with acceptance of peer referral for SUD treatment?

We also describe development of the rural peer intervention.

attributes.title: Smileys & Impression Formation
attributes.description: Gender differences in the effect of smileys on impression formation in digital communication.

q1.value: The Influence of Gender and Smileys on Impression Formation in Digital Communication

q3.value:
Since the introduction of text messages and computer-mediated communication (CMC), both formal and informal relationships are often established online. Smileys can be seen as digital representatives of a real smile and have been developed to give people the opportunity to non-verbally express their feelings and emotions in CMC. Previous research found that using smileys does indeed affect the perception of the sender of a text message. Specifically, smileys reduce perceptions of competence in professional contexts, but no conclusive effect on warmth was observed. Importantly, previous research has not accounted for gender as a moderator of these links.

In this experiment, we test whether the gender of the sender of a message moderates this relationship in a professional context. Participants will see messages with smileys (compared to plain text) sent by female vs. male senders framed as colleagues and it will be assessed how the recipient perceives the personality of the sender (warmth and competence) and how desirable the sender of the message would find it to actually work together with the sender of the message (colleague desirability).

We believe that for men, participants are more likely to discount the non-verbal CMC behavior as a source of incompetence, because this runs counter to the prevalent gender stereotype that men - especially in professional contexts - are competent. For women, on the other hand, "incompetent" non-verbal behavior is in line with gender stereotypes. Therefore, we believe that the effect of using smileys in professional contexts will decrease perceptions of competence, but more strongly for women.

On the flipside, for women "warm" non-verbal behavior is in line with gender stereotyping. Therefore, we believe that the effect of using smileys in professional contexts will increase perceptions of warmth, but more strongly for women.

FInally, because previous research suggests that smileys are seen as inappropriate in a professional setting, we believe using smileys leads to lower ratings of colleague desirability. This effect is expected to be stronger for women, since in a professional context competence is evaluated as more important than warmth. In addition, we expect that the effect of smileys on colleague desirability is mediated by perceived competence and not warmth.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: The senders of e-mails including smileys will be rated as less competent than the senders of plain text messages. This effect will be qualified by the sender's gender and it is predicted that perceived competence is more strongly reduced for female senders.

Hypothesis 2: The senders of e-mails including smileys will be rated as warmer than the senders of plain text messages. This effect will be qualified by the sender's gender and it is predicted that perceived warmth is more strongly increased for female senders .

Hypothesis 3: The senders of e-mails including smileys will be rated as less desirable to work with than the senders of plain text messages. This effect will be qualified by the sender's gender and it is predicted that perceived colleague desirability is more strongly reduced for female senders.

Hypothesis 4: Since the study is framed within a professional context, the effect of smileys on colleague desirability will be mediated by perceived competence, not warmth.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We conduct a 2 (Gender: Female vs. Male) x 2 (Smiley: Smiley vs. No Smiley) within-subjects design.

q9.value: The order of the trials, which messages will be presented with and without a smiley, and which messages will be sent by women and men will be randomized anew for every participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will be conducted online using the platform Prolific Academic. We will recruit at least 146 participants who speak English sufficiently and who are at least 18 years old. The study will take approximately 15 minutes, for which participants will receive a small monetary compensation.

q13.value: The target sample size is at least 146 participants.

q14.value: To determine the sample size, we conducted an a priori power analysis using g*power 3.1. We based this power analysis on very comparable studies, which investigated the effects of smileys on several outcomes. Although none of these studies assessed warmth or competence, their design and the manipulation of the smiley variable were virtually identical to this study. The average observed effect size across nine experiments in this study was dz = 0.63. However, in these studies smileys were included in comparatively shorter text-messages and thus it is likely that their effects will be weaker in the present experiment. Thus, we decided to conservatively halve this effect size and used a target effect size of dz = 0.315 for our power analysis. To be able to detect such an effect with a power of (1-β) = 0.80, N = 82 participants are needed. However, in the present study we plan to conduct six post-hoc comparisons to detect effects of this size. Therefore, in order to guarantee a power of (1-β) = 0.80 for the whole set of hypothesis test, a power of a power of (1-β) = 0.965 for the individual tests (0.965^6=0.807) and consequently N = 146 participants are needed. Only participants who completed the full experiment will be included in the analyses.

q15.value: The data collection will be stopped once the desired sample size is reached.

question.value:
Gender: 
This variable will be manipulated within-participants with two conditions. Randomly selected, half of the email messages participants read during the study will be sent by women, and the other half will be sent by men.

Smileys:
This variable will be manipulated within-participants with two conditions. Randomly selected, half of the email messages participants read during the study will include a smiley, and the other half will consist of plain text.

Warmth:
Perceived warmth will be measured using 5 items that have shown acceptable to good reliabilty in previous research (α = .75). This trait will be measured with a 7-point Likert scale.

Competence:
Perceived competence will be measured using 6 items that have shown acceptable to good reliabilty in previous research (α = .76). This trait will be measured with a 7-point Likert scale.

Colleague desirability:
To measure colleague desirability, participants will be asked: “How likely is it that you would want to work with this person?”. This question will be answered on a single 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (“not likely at all”) to 7 (“extremely likely”).
The responses to all perceived competence and warmth questions will be averaged into a single index.

All analyses will be conducted in SPSS or using the PROCESS macro for SPSS. Hypotheses 1-3 will be tested within three separate repeated-measures ANOVAs with the independent variables Gender (Female vs. Male) and Smiley (Smiley vs. No Smiley), and the dependent variables warmth, competence, and colleague desirability, respectively.

For hypotheses 1-3, post-hoc paired-samples t-tests on competence/warmth/colleague desirability ratings will be conducted (separately for the two genders) to confirm that both men and women who sent a message including a smiley are perceived as warmer/less competent/less desirable as a colleague. 

Hypothesis 4 will be tested within a moderated parallel mediation framework (conducted with the SPSS macro PROCESS) with Smiley (contrast-coded: -0.5 = plain text email vs. 0.5 = email including a smiley) as the independent variable, Warmth and Competence as continuous mediators, Gender (contrast-coded: -0.5 = female vs. 0.5 = male) as the moderator, and colleague desirability as the continuous criterion.

q20.value: All continuous dependent measures with multiple items will be averaged for the analyses.

q21.value:
For all ANOVAs, the conventional significance criterion of .05 will be used. 

For the directional post-hoc tests, the same criterion, but in a one-sided test, will be used.

For the mediation analysis (Hypothesis 4), instead of testing significance, regression weights and 95% CIs will be estimated using 5,000 bootstrap samples. It will be concluded that effects are significant within this framework if the confidence interval does not include 0.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from the study if their English proficiency is not sufficient.

q23.value: Missing data will be list-wise deleted.

q25.value: All materials will be uploaded to this project and all references (also for the measures used in this study) will be provided on the project page, too.

attributes.title: Infants’ understanding of plant structure: Touching study

q1.value: Infants’ understanding of plant structure: Touching study

q3.value:
Humans’ interaction with plants has a long history. While plants are sources of food, some plants have evolved defenses against animals. Therefore, successfully determining which plants in a local environment are edible or touchable is a critical skill from an evolutionary standpoint. We are interested in investigating the aspects of plants that enable us to distinguish touchable plants from poisonous ones. 

Previous studies suggest that even young infants seem to differentiate plants from artifacts and treat them differently. Infants are hesitant to touch plants rather than artifacts (Wertz & Wynn, 2014a; Włodarczyk, Elsner, Schmitterer, & Wertz, 2018), and they exhibit more social looking to adults when presented with plants compared to other object types (Elsner & Wertz, 2019).

In the current study, we examine infants’ differentiation between plants from artifacts by manipulating one feature of plants: the skeletal structure. The skeletal structure of plants has unique properties – organized around a skeleton with a primary vertical axis and roughly symmetrical, branching limbs and roots – distinctively different from animals and artifacts (Feldman & Singh, 2006).

We present two stimulus objects to infants. The two stimuli are manipulated in the way that the only difference between them is the skeletal structure. We hypothesize that infants will exhibit a longer latency and more social looking toward adults before touching the plant-like structure than touching the artifact which has non-plant-like structure. Statistical tests will be run after data collection and coding.

q4.value: If infants use the skeletal structure information to distinguish plants from artifacts, they will exhibit a longer latency and more social looking toward adults before touching the plant-like structure than touching the Non-plant-like structure.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
The coder will assess whether the experimenter's behavior during the object presentation phase may have inadvertently influenced infants. One third of the videos will be randomly selected and rated by two independent coders. The portion of the video that shows the stimulus object will be covered or removed so that the coders are blind to trial type. Then based on the experimenter's facial expressions and movements, the coders rate the expected object type that has been presented (plant-like vs. non-plant-like structure).

Then, data will be analyzed by a binomial test to examine whether the proportion of correctly rated objects is significantly different from chance. If the result is not significant, it indicates that the experimenter did not give cues to participants that could systematically affect their responses.

question.value:
Parent questionnaire 
Since the previous study found a positive correlation between infants’ reluctance to touch plants and the number of observations of their parents caring for plants (Wertz & Wynn, 2014a), we will also ask parents to complete a questionnaire before the main experiment. As in the previous study, parents will be asked to rate on a five point Likert scale (1 = never, to 5 = nearly every day) (i) how often their child interacts with plants, (ii) how often they point out or name different plants for their child, (iii) how often their child sees them caring for plants around the house/in a garden, (iv) how often their child tries to touch indoor plants and (v) outdoor plants, (vi) how often they stop their child from touching plants, and (vii) whether they stop their child from touching all plants (Yes/No).  

Main experiment
Adapted from the studies of Wertz & Wynn (2014a) and Włodarczyk et al., (2018), infants sit on their parents’ laps across a table from an experimenter who places two objects, one at a time, in front of the infant while saying “Look what I’ve got”. The experimenter only touches the bottom of the structures, a container, throughout the experiment. Parents keep their eyes closed throughout, and the experimenter looks down at the bottom of the structures with a neutral expression. Presentation order of the two objects are counterbalanced. 

Trials terminate (i) when the infant touches the top part of the object, or (ii) 30 seconds elapse without a touch. A touch is counted as the moment that any part of the infant’s hand comes in contact with the object. 

If infants fail to touch both objects, the experiment repeats the procedure for a second round of testing.

q9.value: The presentation order of the two objects is randomized and counterbalanced. Some infants will be presented with the plant-like structure first and the non-plant-like structure second; others will be presented the non-plant-like structure first and the plan-like structure second.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be contacted from an existing database of infants whose parents have signed up to participate in studies at Harvard. Participants are given $5 for reimbursement and a small toy/souvenir. Infants will only be contacted if they are full term.

q13.value: N = 42 full-term 8- to 18-month-old infants in each condition, or until we have a Bayes Factor of 8 for the Bayesian t-test whether there is a difference in latency before touching the plant-like structure compared to the non-plant-like structure.

q14.value: This number is based on the previous findings (Wertz & Wynn, 2014a, N = 47 in Experiment 1, N = 44 in Experiment 2; Włodarczyk et al., 2018, N = 42; Elsner & Wertz, 2019, N = 42), which provided positive results with the similar procedure.

q15.value: N = 42 participants, or until we have a Bayes Factor of 8 for the Bayesian t-test whether there is a difference in latency before touching the plant-like structure compared to the non-plant-like structure.

question.value:
Infants are presented with two stimuli, one at a time. 

Our stimuli are two crafted objects, manipulated in the way that the only difference is their skeletal structures (Please see pictures below). One stimulus, the “plant-like structure,” has two tree-like structure, with trunks, branches, and leaves. The other stimulus, the “non-plant-like structure,” has a structure made of two vertical pillars and two horizontal connections in between.

Both stimuli (see Figure 1) are made of two large wood pieces, eight small wood pieces, and eighteen leaves. Each of them is placed in a rectangular container filled with natural dirt.

Video recording
Each experiment session is recorded using two professional video cameras. One video captures the infant, the parent, the stimuli objects, and the experimenter, and it includes the entire experiment procedure and all the infants’ behaviors. The other video captures the experimenter to measure his or her behaviors. 


Coding procedure (adapted from Elsner & Wertz, 2019)
1.	Infants’ touch behavior
-	Infants’ touch behavior towards the top part of the objects is coded during each trial. Each trial begins when the experimenter releases his hands from the container of the stimulus object after placing it on the table in front of the infant and ended as one of the termination criteria is met (as described in the “study design” section above). A “touch” is coded as any part of the infant’s hand coming into contact with the stimulus object, excluding the bottom part (e.g. the soil). 
-	Latency, or the elapsed time before infants first make contact with the stimulus object, is coded during each trial. 

2.	Infants’ social looking
-	Infants’ social looks are coded as the looks at adults' (experimenter or parent) face area that occurs immediately after fixating on a presented object. 
-	The number of social looks before the infants’ touch with the stimulus object is coded during each trial. 

3.	Coding experimenter behavior
-	As mentioned in the Design Plan above, to assess whether the experimenter’s behavior during the object presentation phase may have inadvertently influenced infants, a randomly selected third of the videos will be coded by two independent coders who rated the experimenter’s behavior during each trial. Based on the experimenter’s facial expressions and movements, the coders rate the expected object type that has been presented (plant-like vs. non-plant-like structure).

To analyze whether infants are more reluctant to reach out and touch the plant-like than the non-plant-like structure, Bayesian paired sample t-test infants’ mean trial duration for each object type (plant-like and non-plant-like structure) will be conducted. The default prior would be used (Cauchy scale = .707). Also, the number of infants who take longer to touch the plant-like than the non-plant-like structure will be tested by Bayesian binomial test (Beta prior parameter a = 1, b =1). Third, we will use Bayesian paired sample t-test to examine the effect of object type on infants’ number of social looks (Cauchy scale = .707). Last, to examine whether infants’ specific prior experiences with plants influence their behavioral responses, we will conduct Bayesian correlation test between each question in the parent questionnaire and infants’ reluctance to touch the plant-like object (Stretched Bata prior = 1).

q21.value: For Bayes Factors, we will follow the guidelines outlined in Lee and Wagenmakers (2013) for interpreting the strength of evidence.

q22.value:
Parental influence
1)	Parent directing an infant’s behavior towards/away from the objects 
2)	Parent peeking at the infant during the test trials 
3)	Parent interferes with baby’s attention (e.g., saying something during the experiment or doing something that is excessively distracting like trying to put a pacifier in the babies mouth repeatedly)
4)	Other forms of interference (e.g., failure to follow instructions)
5)     Parent stopping the study

Infants’ responses
1)	No response – infants touch neither of them during 30 s in both pairs of the test trials.  
2)	Fussiness or cry – determined by the experimenter or caregiver, that ends in the middle of the test trials. 
3)     Grasping soil – infants grab soil on the bottom of the box and bring it to them, the trial will be ended. 

Experimenter error
1)	Experimenter presenting the wrong version of the stimuli
2)	Experimenter error when presenting the stimuli 

Technical failure
1)	Loss of video record of a study before all data are collected from video

Infants will be excluded as the experiment is actively running if they meet any of the above-mentioned criteria either determined live at the time of the study or when reviewed or coded offline after the experiment.

q23.value: If an infant does not touch any of the two objects during 30 s in both pairs of the test trials, that infant will not be included in the analysis.

Infants will be excluded as the experiment is actively running if they meet any of the above-mentioned criteria either determined live at the time of the study or when reviewed or coded offline after the experiment.
registration_responses.q23: If an infant does not touch any of the two objects during 30 s in both pairs of the test trials, that infant will not be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Parent questionnaire 
Since the previous study found a positive correlation between infants’ reluctance to touch plants and the number of observations of their parents caring for plants (Wertz & Wynn, 2014a), we will also ask parents to complete a questionnaire before the main experiment. As in the previous study, parents will be asked to rate on a five point Likert scale (1 = never, to 5 = nearly every day) (i) how often their child interacts with plants, (ii) how often they point out or name different plants for their child, (iii) how often their child sees them caring for plants around the house/in a garden, (iv) how often their child tries to touch indoor plants and (v) outdoor plants, (vi) how often they stop their child from touching plants, and (vii) whether they stop their child from touching all plants (Yes/No).  

Main experiment
Adapted from the studies of Wertz & Wynn (2014a) and Włodarczyk et al., (2018), infants sit on their parents’ laps across a table from an experimenter who places two objects, one at a time, in front of the infant while saying “Look what I’ve got”. The experimenter only touches the bottom of the structures, a container, throughout the experiment. Parents keep their eyes closed throughout, and the experimenter looks down at the bottom of the structures with a neutral expression. Presentation order of the two objects are counterbalanced. 

Trials terminate (i) when the infant touches the top part of the object, or (ii) 30 seconds elapse without a touch. A touch is counted as the moment that any part of the infant’s hand comes in contact with the object. 

If infants fail to touch both objects, the experiment repeats the procedure for a second round of testing.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be contacted from an existing database of infants whose parents have signed up to participate in studies at Harvard. Participants are given $5 for reimbursement and a small toy/souvenir. Infants will only be contacted if they are full term.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Infants are presented with two stimuli, one at a time. 

Our stimuli are two crafted objects, manipulated in the way that the only difference is their skeletal structures (Please see pictures below). One stimulus, the “plant-like structure,” has two tree-like structure, with trunks, branches, and leaves. The other stimulus, the “non-plant-like structure,” has a structure made of two vertical pillars and two horizontal connections in between.

Both stimuli (see Figure 1) are made of two large wood pieces, eight small wood pieces, and eighteen leaves. Each of them is placed in a rectangular container filled with natural dirt.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Video recording
Each experiment session is recorded using two professional video cameras. One video captures the infant, the parent, the stimuli objects, and the experimenter, and it includes the entire experiment procedure and all the infants’ behaviors. The other video captures the experimenter to measure his or her behaviors. 


Coding procedure (adapted from Elsner & Wertz, 2019)
1.	Infants’ touch behavior
-	Infants’ touch behavior towards the top part of the objects is coded during each trial. Each trial begins when the experimenter releases his hands from the container of the stimulus object after placing it on the table in front of the infant and ended as one of the termination criteria is met (as described in the “study design” section above). A “touch” is coded as any part of the infant’s hand coming into contact with the stimulus object, excluding the bottom part (e.g. the soil). 
-	Latency, or the elapsed time before infants first make contact with the stimulus object, is coded during each trial. 

2.	Infants’ social looking
-	Infants’ social looks are coded as the looks at adults' (experimenter or parent) face area that occurs immediately after fixating on a presented object. 
-	The number of social looks before the infants’ touch with the stimulus object is coded during each trial. 

3.	Coding experimenter behavior
-	As mentioned in the Design Plan above, to assess whether the experimenter’s behavior during the object presentation phase may have inadvertently influenced infants, a randomly selected third of the videos will be coded by two independent coders who rated the experimenter’s behavior during each trial. Based on the experimenter’s facial expressions and movements, the coders rate the expected object type that has been presented (plant-like vs. non-plant-like structure).
registration_responses.q19.question: To analyze whether infants are more reluctant to reach out and touch the plant-like than the non-plant-like structure, Bayesian paired sample t-test infants’ mean trial duration for each object type (plant-like and non-plant-like structure) will be conducted. The default prior would be used (Cauchy scale = .707). Also, the number of infants who take longer to touch the plant-like than the non-plant-like structure will be tested by Bayesian binomial test (Beta prior parameter a = 1, b =1). Third, we will use Bayesian paired sample t-test to examine the effect of object type on infants’ number of social looks (Cauchy scale = .707). Last, to examine whether infants’ specific prior experiences with plants influence their behavioral responses, we will conduct Bayesian correlation test between each question in the parent questionnaire and infants’ reluctance to touch the plant-like object (Stretched Bata prior = 1).

attributes.title: SUD treatment, irrational beliefs, food craving and selection.

comments.value:
At the time of this posting, data collection had begun.

Replication

H1: Persons in treatment for SUD will have higher impulsivity, food craving, and BMI

H2: Food craving will be positively correlated with impulsivity.

H3: Persons in treatment for SUD will select more food (items, energy) than persons in the control group. 
    H3a: This behavior may be moderated by reward responsiveness and may be selective for sweet and/or other high energy foods.
    H3b: This behavior may be mediated by impulsivity and/or food craving.

New

H4: Food craving will be positively correlated with “food addiction”

H5: Anhedonia and irrational beliefs about food will each be correlated with food addiction, food craving, and impulsivity.

H6: Length of treatment period and breadth of drug use may be correlated with anhedonia, food craving, and impulsivity. If so, anhedonia may moderate food selection in H3. 

H7: Anhedonia and irrational beliefs about food may be moderators or mediators of the relationship described in H3

H8: Persons in treatment for SUD will have higher anhedonia, food craving, and BMI. All may depend on how long they have been in recovery.

Sample: members of the adult community (Qualtrics panel) half of whom are in recovery for SUD. 

Variables:
Irrational food beliefs: IFBS
Food craving: FCQ-T-r
Reward responsiveness: RRS
Food misuse: modified Yale food addiction scale 2 (mYFAS-2) 
Anhedonia: TEPS
Impulsivity: Short UPPS-P
BMI 
Gender 
Age
